Toolkit

Wordmark

Toggle: Notes Code

Aside from www.wiley.com, the Wiley wordmark should only be found in the footer of a digital product. See Footers for details.

Weâ€™ve provided the wordmark in various formats for easy download and usage.

  • Our Wiley wordmark is only ever seen in black or white
  • For more information on how to use the Wiley wordmark, please consult the One Wiley Brand Guidelines
EPS | SVG | PNG
EPS | SVG | PNG 
<div class="ow-wordmarks">
        	<div class="ow-wordmark">
        		<img class="ow-wordmark__image ow-wordmark__image--black" alt="Black Wiley wordmark" src="/assets/toolkit/images/wiley-wordmark-black.svg">
        		<span class="ow-wordmark__links"><a href="/assets/toolkit/images/wordmark/wiley-wordmark-black.eps">EPS</a> | <a href="/assets/toolkit/images/wordmark/wiley-wordmark-black.svg">SVG</a> | <a href="/assets/toolkit/images/wordmark/wiley-wordmark-black.png">PNG</a></span>
        	</div>
        	<div class="ow-wordmark">
        		<img class="ow-wordmark__image ow-wordmark__image--white" alt="White Wiley wordmark" src="/assets/toolkit/images/wiley-wordmark-white.svg">
        		<span class="ow-wordmark__links"><a href="/assets/toolkit/images/wordmark/wiley-wordmark-white.eps">EPS</a> | <a href="/assets/toolkit/images/wordmark/wiley-wordmark-white.svg">SVG</a> | <a href="/assets/toolkit/images/wordmark/wiley-wordmark-white.png">PNG</a></span>

Colors

Toggle: Notes Code

The Wiley color palette is an important part of our brand identity. When designing UIs, we encourage you to choose from a subset of the secondary colors and to use them only to enhance the usability of your design. If you can easily start implementing this color palette on your digital product, please start doing so immediately. Otherwise, please implement with your next redesign.

Our extended secondary color palette helps to make our communications more engaging. There are six key colors in our secondary palette and within each of these are three tones â€“ a light tone, mid tone and dark tone.

Core and secondary color palette

wiley colors

Tints

If the need arises, tints can be used. They can be implemented either through opacity changes or using the absolute values as described here.

        <h3>Tints</h3>
        <p>If the need arises, tints can be used. They can be implemented either through opacity changes or using the absolute values as described <a href="tints.html">here</a>.</p>

Typography

Toggle: Notes Code

Below is a set of recommended text styles for basic HTML tags. If you can easily start implementing this font on your digital product, please start doing so immediately. Otherwise, please implement with your next redesign. Here are some specifics about font faces and writing style:

  • Our primary font for online usage is Open Sans which can be found here: Open Sans at Google Fonts
  • We are currently discussing including a monospaced typeface and serif typeface to broaden the font palette for UI design only. Please check back regularly for updates.
  • Please use 'sentence case' where possible
  • Use all caps sparingly and for key information or headings only
  • Unless specified otherwise, Wiley's corporate written language is American English

Headings

Heading Level 1 - Please restrict to one use per page

Heading Level 2 - heading

Heading Level 3 - sub-heading

Heading Level 4 - Key information and links/call-to-actions

Heading Level 5 - Key supporting information
Heading Level 6 - legislation and copyright

Paragraph

A paragraph (from the Greek paragraphos, "to write beside" or "written beside") is a self-contained unit of a discourse in writing dealing with a particular point or idea. A paragraph consists of one or more sentences. Though not required by the syntax of any language, paragraphs are usually an expected part of formal writing, used to organize longer prose.

Blockquote

A block quotation (also known as a long quotation or extract) is a quotation in a written document, which is set off from the main text as a paragraph, or block of text, and typically distinguished visually using indentation and a different typeface or smaller size quotation.

<h3>Headings</h3>
        
        <h1>Heading Level 1 - Please restrict to one use per page</h1>
        <h2>Heading Level 2 - heading</h2>
        <h3>Heading Level 3 - sub-heading</h3>
        <h4>Heading Level 4 - Key information and links/call-to-actions</h4>
        <h5>Heading Level 5 - Key supporting information</h5>
        <h6>Heading Level 6 - legislation and copyright</h6>
        
        <h3>Paragraph</h3>
        
        <p>A paragraph (from the Greek paragraphos, "to write beside" or "written beside") is a self-contained unit of a discourse in writing dealing with a particular point or idea. A paragraph consists of one or more sentences. Though not required by the syntax
        	of any language, paragraphs are usually an expected part of formal writing, used to organize longer prose.</p>
        
        <h3>Blockquote</h3>
        
        <blockquote>
        	<p>A block quotation (also known as a long quotation or extract) is a quotation in a written document, which is set off from the main text as a paragraph, or block of text, and typically distinguished visually using indentation and a different typeface
        		or smaller size quotation.</p>
        </blockquote>

The network should be used sparingly within UI design and adopted primarily to draw focus to key information.

Usability

Toggle: Notes Code

Best Practices for Designing an Interface

Everything stems from knowing your users, including understanding their goals, skills, preferences, and tendencies.Â  Once you know about your user, make sure to consider the following when designing your interface:

  • Keep the interface simple. The best interfaces are almost invisible to the user. They avoid unnecessary elements and are clear in the language they use on labels and in messaging.
  • Create consistency and use common UI elements.Â By usingÂ common elementsÂ in your UI, users feel more comfortable and are able to get things done more quickly.Â  It is also important to create patterns in language, layout and design throughout the site to help facilitate efficiency. Once a user learns how to do something, they should be able to transfer that skill to other parts of the site.
  • Be purposeful in page layout.Â Consider the spatial relationships between items on the page and structure the page based on importance. Careful placement of items can help draw attention to the most important pieces of information and can aid scanning and readability.
  • Strategically use color and texture.Â You can direct attention toward or redirect attention away from items using color, light, contrast, and texture to your advantage.
  • Use typography to create hierarchy and clarity.Â Carefully consider how you use typeface. Different sizes, fonts, and arrangement of the text to help increase scanability, legibility and readability.
  • Make sure that the system communicates whatâ€™s happening. Always inform your users of location, actions, changes in state, or errors. The use of various UI elements to communicate status and, if necessary, next steps can reduce frustration for your user.
  • Think about the defaults. By carefully thinking about and anticipating the goals people bring to your site, you can create defaults that reduce the burden on the user.Â  This becomes particularly important when it comes to form design where you might have an opportunity to have some fields pre-chosen or filled out.
  • Touch devices and hit areas. The physical size of CTAs are important when designing for touch screen. 44px/1cm is a good starting point.
  • Animation Responsiveness should never be sacrificed for fancy animations. However, motion can be used to describe spatial relationships, functionality, and intention.

Accessibility

Toggle: Notes Code

At Wiley, we work to meet the requirements for 'WCAG 2.0: Level AA' compliance. A full checklist of the guidelines can be found here.

UX Architects, UI developers and UI designers all play a significant part in meeting the accessibility requirements. Here are some key points for UI designers:

  • Text or diagrams, and their background, have a luminosity contrast ratio of at least 5:1. Click here for an online color contrast checker tool.
  • A mechanism is available to turn off background audio that plays automatically, without requiring the user to turn off all audio.
  • Content does not blink for more than three seconds, or a method is available to stop all blinking content in the Web unit or authored component.
  • Content can be paused by the user unless the timing or movement is part of an activity where timing or movement is essential.
  • A full checklist of the guidelines can be found here.
  • A useful article that outlines the various responsibilities regarding accessibility can be found here
